titleStmt.title: Keyword taxonomy accompanying accompanying the "Corpus de novelas hispanoamericanas del siglo XIX (conha19)"

availability.p: The file is provided here with the Public Domain Mark Declaration and can be re-used without restrictions.

category.catDesc: Metadata concerning the author of the work
To which continent does the author belong by birth and/or residence?
To which country does the author belong by birth and/or residence?
To which country does the author belong by birth?
To which country does the author belong by death?
To which country does the author belong by nationality?
e.g. png, jpeg, tiff files or a PDF with images or text that cannot be extracted easily
Institution or platform by/on which the source was published.
Biblioteca Digital de Castilla y León
La novela corta: una biblioteca virtual
Biblioteca Digital de la Biblioteca Nacional de Cuba José Martí
The kind of edition of the source.
The source edition is classified as "historical" if it belongs to the same historical period as the corpus (1830-1910).
The source edition is classified as "modern" if it has been published after the historical period of the corpus (after 1910).
Metadata concerning the publication of the work
Metadata concerning the first publication of the work
In which country has the work been published first?
In which kind of medium has the work been published first?
In what form has the work been published first: as an independent publication, a dependent publication, or as part of a collection of works of the same author?
Has the work ever been published independently (in book form)?
What is the main language the text is written in?
What is the main form of the text (prose, verse)?
Metadata concerning the genre of the work
The subgenre as indicated in the main title, subtitle or series title.
The subgenre as indicated explicitly and literally in the title. This is an open category.
When there is no explicit genre signal in the title.
The subgenre as indicated by implicit genre signals in the title. This is an open category.
When there is no implicit genre signal in the title.

The subgenre as given (explicitly and literally) in the paratext of the work (beyond the title). This may include further information on title pages (e.g. quotes), in dedications, prefaces, headings, table of contents. etc. This is an open category.
The subgenre as given explicitly and literally in the paratext.
When the paratext is not available because no historical edition could be consulted.
When the subgenre is not mentioned explicitly in the paratext.
The subgenre as indicated by implicit genre signals in the paratext. This is an open category.
When the paratext is not available because no historical edition could be consulted.
When there is no implicit genre signal in the paratext.
The subgenre as given in statements made by contemporaries. This is an open category.
The subgenre as given explicitly and literally in statements made by contemporaries. This is an open category.
The subgenre as derived from genre signals in the opening of the text (e.g. in the first chapter). This is an open category.
The subgenre as interpreted from genre signals in the opening of the text. This is an open category.
A summary of text.genre.subgenre.title, text.genre.subgenre.paratext, text.genre.subgenre.contemp, and text.genre.subgenre.opening.
A summary of text.genre.subgenre.title.explicit, text.genre.subgenre.paratext.explicit, and text.genre.subgenre.contemp.explicit.
If the subgenre is not mentioned explicity in either the title, the paratext, or by contemporaries.
A normalized version of the historical subgenre label. This is an open category, but a list of values occurring in the corpus and the bibliography is curated here to ensure consistency.
If the subgenre is not mentioned explicity in either the title, the paratext, or by contemporaries.

A summary of text.genre.subgenre.title.implicit, text.genre.subgenre.paratext.implicit, and text.genre.subgenre.opening.interp. This is an open category, but a list of values occurring in the corpus and the bibliography is curated here to ensure consistency.
If there are no implicit genre signals in either the title, the paratext or in the text opening.
The subgenre as given (explicitly and literally) in a literary history or critical research literature. This is an open category.

The subgenre as interpreted from statements in literary histories or critical research literature. This is an open category, but a list of values occurring in the corpus and the bibliography is curated here to ensure consistency.
A summary of the historical and literary historical subgenre assignments.
A summary of the historical subgenre labels that are given explicitly or signalled implicitly in titles are other paratextual elements.
Subgenre labels that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels that are signalled implicitly.
A summary of the thematic historical or literary historical subgenre labels.
Thematic subgenre labels that are given explicitly.
Thematic subgenre labels that are signalled implicitly.
Thematic subgenre labels that are assigned by literary historians.
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to literary currents.
Subgenre labels referring to literary currents that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to literary currents that are signalled implicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to literary currents that are assigned by literary historians.
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to the cultural, geographical or national identity.
Subgenre labels referring to identity that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to identity that are signalled implicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to identity that are assigned by literary historians.
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to the mode the text is narrated in (attitude, intention, reality, medium, or representation).
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to the attitude of the author or narrator towards the text.
Subgenre labels referring to the attitude that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the attitude that are signalled implicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the attitude that are assigned by literary historians.
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to the intention that the author or narrator has with the text.
Subgenre labels referring to the intention that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the intention that are signalled implicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the intention that are assigned by literary historians.
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to the relationship of the text to reality.
Subgenre labels referring to reality that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to reality that are signalled implicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to reality that are assigned by literary historians.
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to the medium the text is using.
Subgenre labels referring to the medium that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the medium that are signalled implicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the medium that are assigned by literary historians.
A summary of the historical or literary historical subgenre labels referring to how the text is represented linguistically.
Subgenre labels referring to the representation that are given explicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the representation that are signalled implicitly.
Subgenre labels referring to the representation that are assigned by literary historians.
The primary sign used in the novel to indicate direct speech or thought. (There may be other, secondary signs.)
The type of the primary speech sign used in the novel (single or double).
The primary continent of the setting.
The primary country of the setting.
If the narrated time is contemporary to the author (during the author's lifetime) or if it is not marked at all.
If the narrated time is within 30 years before the author's birth date.
If the narrated time is more than 30 years before the author's birth date.
If the narrated time is more than 100 years after the author's birth date.
If the narrated time is contemporary to the publication date (within 30 years before and after) or if it is not marked at all.
If the narrated time is between 30 and 60 years before the publication date.
If the narrated time is more than 60 years before the publication date.
If the narrated time is more than 30 years after the publication date.

With this category, the prestige of the text is described as high or low. Prestige is understood here as how the text has been valued in the 20th and 21st centuries. To determine the prestige, each novel was looked up in the WorldCat and whereever there is a new edition of the work published between 1960 and 2020, it is classified as high prestige, otherwise as low. The entries in the WorldCat were checked on 4-5 June, 2020.
